title: Hearing Aids for Tinnitus
chief_complaint: I have a whistling in the center of my head that has been there for over 10 years. It is destroying my quality of life.

problem_summary.course: Chronic and troublesome; previous treatments (ENT, hearing aids) provided minimal benefit.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Severe distress, agitation, depression, anxiety, sleep disturbance.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Rarely engages in social situations; sleep is affected; feels ability to enjoy life is negatively impacted.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Desperate for relief; previously tried hearing aids without success but willing to try again.

history.present_illness: Patient reports disabling tinnitus perceived as a whistling in the center of the head. He is severely distressed and admits to being depressed.
history.otologic_history: Previous head injury with loss of consciousness in a traffic accident.
history.noise_exposure_history: Long history of artillery noise exposure in the military for over 20 years without hearing protection.
history.medical_psych_history: General physical health is good. Appears depressed and anxious. Prescribed Zopiclone (3.5 mg) for sleep.
history.prior_management: Seen several ENT specialists with minimal benefit. Previously tried hearing aids with no appreciable improvement.
history.patient_goals: Relief from tinnitus; improvement in sleep.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to severe high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss at 3000 to 8000 Hz. Hearing is within normal limits from 250 to 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Type A bilaterally (normal middle ear pressure, compliance, and ear canal volume).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Not completed because the patient reported no difficulty hearing.

history.present_illness: Patient reported some relief from a bedside digital environmental sound generator provided at the previous visit (enabled easier sleep), but still experiencing disabling tinnitus.
history.prior_management: Counseling provided on tinnitus mechanisms. Sound enrichment devices issued.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Fitting
tests.key_findings: Fitted with bilateral digital BTE hearing aids with slim-tubes and open domes. Two programs created.

numeric_results.Program_1_Strategy: Tinnitus relief: Maximize audibility of soft sounds (compression kneepoint ~40 dB SPL), Noise Reduction OFF, Omnidirectional mic.
numeric_results.Program_2_Strategy: Speech recognition: NAL-NL1 targets, Noise Reduction ON, Adaptive Directionality ON.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity through 2000 Hz, sloping to a severe high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Despite the high-frequency loss, the patient reports no subjective hearing difficulty in quiet or with TV/phone. The primary audiologic issue is severe, disabling tinnitus (THI 72%) associated with the region of hearing loss.
counseling_points: Even though you feel you hear well at home, your high-frequency hearing loss deprives your brain of environmental sound stimulation, which can make the tinnitus seem louder ('starkness' of tinnitus).
Hearing aids can provide sound enrichment to reduce the contrast between the tinnitus and the background, making the ringing less intrusive.

We have set up a specific 'quiet' program that amplifies very soft sounds (like the hum of a fridge or fan) to help mask the tinnitus, with noise reduction turned off so you can hear those soothing background noises.
A second program is available for noisy situations where you need to focus on speech clarity.
Using sound generators at night (like the sound of the sea) can help distract your brain and improve sleep.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is visibly distressed, agitated, and depressed.
